G.L. c. 218, \u00a719.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper under G.L. c. 218, §19 and G.L. c. 223, as the Defendant transacts business and maintains property within Essex County, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 223.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper under G.L. c. 218, §19 and G.L. c. 223, as the Defendant transacts business and maintains property within Essex County, Massachusetts.

Mass. R. Civ. P. 3.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to Mass. R. Civ. P. 3 and the venue provisions of G.L. c. 223, §8, because the events giving rise to this action occurred in Lynn, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a78.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to Mass. R. Civ. P. 3 and the venue provisions of G.L. c. 223, §8, because the events giving rise to this action occurred in Lynn, Massachusetts.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, landlords and property managers owe tenants a duty to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition, including ensuring that smoke and fire safety devices are operational.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is a premises-liability case about the duty owed by an occupier of land and the abandonment of the rigid common‑law categories of invitee and licensee. It does not address landlord‑tenant obligations or the specific duty to maintain premises, including smoke and fire safety devices, in a reasonably safe condition. The provided excerpt, a concurrence focused on treatment of trespassers, contains no discussion of landlords, property managers, or fire/smoke safety equipment, so it does not support the cited proposition.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a “licensee” rather than an “invitee,” or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that “trespassers” stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential.

Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, landlords and property managers owe tenants a duty to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition, including ensuring that smoke and fire safety devices are operational.
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).support_reasoning: The case clearly holds that Massachusetts landlords owe a general duty of reasonable care to maintain rental premises in a reasonably safe condition for tenants and their guests. However, the opinion does not address smoke detectors, fire alarms, or fire safety devices at all, nor does it discuss any specific duty regarding such devices. Thus it supports the broad negligence duty toward safe premises, but not the more specific proposition about ensuring smoke and fire safety devices are operational.
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).relevant_excerpt: “Henceforth, landlords as other persons must exercise reasonable care not to subject others to an unreasonable risk of harm. A landlord must act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.”

G.L. c. 143, \u00a73R.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty under G.L. c. 143, §3R, 527 C.M.R. 1.00 (Massachusetts Comprehensive Fire Safety Code), and relevant municipal housing codes to install and maintain working smoke detectors in common areas.

527 C.M.R. 1.00 (Massachusetts Comprehen.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty under G.L. c. 143, §3R, 527 C.M.R. 1.00 (Massachusetts Comprehensive Fire Safety Code), and relevant municipal housing codes to install and maintain working smoke detectors in common areas.

Jean W. v. Commonwealth, 414 Mass. 496,.proposition: Defendant’s breach constitutes negligence under Restatement (Second) of Torts § 323, which Massachusetts courts have adopted to impose liability where one undertakes to render services necessary for protection but performs negligently.
Jean W. v. Commonwealth, 414 Mass. 496,.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt is only the brief rescript reversing a dismissal and remanding; it contains no discussion of Restatement (Second) of Torts § 323, negligent undertaking, or Massachusetts’ adoption of that section. While Jean W. v. Commonwealth may elsewhere in the full opinion address § 323, nothing in the supplied text establishes or affirms the specific legal principle claimed, so based solely on this text the citation does not support the proposition.
Jean W. v. Commonwealth, 414 Mass. 496,.relevant_excerpt: The judgment of the Superior Court dismissing the complaint is reversed. The plaintiffs shall have thirty days from the date of the issuance of the rescript to file an amended complaint in the Superior Court. The case is remanded to the Superior Court for further proceedings.

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).proposition: Defendant’s negligence foreseeably caused Plaintiff’s injuries and property damage, as the absence of an operational smoke alarm delayed Plaintiff’s evacuation.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).support_reasoning: This case concerns a homeowner’s duty and foreseeability relating to negligent storage of firearms, not smoke alarms, fires, evacuation timing, or property damage from fire. The court’s foreseeability analysis addresses criminal misuse of a stolen gun, not delayed evacuation due to a non‑operational smoke detector. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the proposition that a defendant’s negligence in failing to maintain a smoke alarm foreseeably caused injury by delaying evacuation.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care… We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’ … A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor.” (447 Mass. at 146-47).

Banushi v. Dorfman, 438 Mass. 242 (2002).proposition: The following authorities support Defendant’s duty and breach:
Banushi v. Dorfman, 438 Mass. 242 (2002).support_reasoning: The proposition says this case supports the defendant’s duty and breach, but Banushi v. Dorfman holds that G.L. c. 143, § 51 does not apply to an owner-occupied two-family home with one rented unit and therefore does not impose strict liability on such a homeowner. The court explicitly declines to find statutory duty or liability under § 51 for this type of property and affirms summary judgment for the defendants. Thus, the opinion undermines, rather than supports, a claimed duty and breach by the defendant under that statute.
Banushi v. Dorfman, 438 Mass. 242 (2002).relevant_excerpt: “An owner-occupied two-family home in which the owner rents one unit to a tenant is not a ‘building’ within the terms of the statute. Although the owner may derive some minimal income from the rental, it is not the type of commercial, public use, assembly, or workplace structure contemplated by the statute. ‘The large number of owners of [these types of homes] in the Commonwealth should not be exposed to expanded civil liability deriving from the regulatory provisions of chapter 143 except by express and clear legislation evidencing that intention.’ … Renting one portion of one’s own home does not bring the homeowner within the terms of the statute.”

Piquette v. City of Fall River, 2023 WL.raw_text: Piquette v. City of Fall River, 2023 WL 1234567 (Mass. App. Ct. 2023)
Piquette v. City of Fall River, 2023 WL.proposition: The following authorities support Defendant’s duty and breach:

G.L. c. 186, \u00a715F.proposition: The following authorities support Defendant’s duty and breach:

G.L. c. 143, \u00a7\u00a73T\u20133Z.proposition: The following authorities support Defendant’s duty and breach:

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: The following authorities support Defendant’s duty and breach:
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses a premises owner’s duty regarding snow and ice and expressly holds that owners owe lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care to protect them from hazards created by such conditions. It abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction and makes clear that if a property owner knows or should know of dangerous snow/ice, failure to take reasonable remedial measures can constitute negligence. That framework supports citing the case for a defendant’s duty (and potential breach) in a snow-and-ice slip-and-fall context.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.’… If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

Griffin v. General Motors Corp., 380 Mas.raw_text: Griffin v. General Motors Corp., 380 Mass. 362 (1980)
Griffin v. General Motors Corp., 380 Mas.proposition: The following authorities support Defendant’s duty and breach:
Griffin v. General Motors Corp., 380 Mas.support_reasoning: The proposition claims the case as authority for Defendant’s duty and breach. Griffin is a products-liability/negligent-design appeal focused on evidentiary rulings, jury instructions (experiments, future earning capacity, interest, taxes), and excessiveness of damages. The opinion does not analyze or define the manufacturer’s duty of care or what constitutes breach in any substantive way; it assumes negligence was a jury issue and addresses only trial-management questions. Thus it does not provide authority on the existence or contours of a defendant’s duty or breach.
Griffin v. General Motors Corp., 380 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff’s automobile, manufactured by the defendant, caught fire while she was driving it, and she was severely burned. On a theory of negligent design, a jury has awarded her $1,000,000 in damages… The defendant’s appeal presents evidentiary issues, issues with respect to the instructions to the jury, and a claim that the damages awarded are excessive.”
